title: Verb Forms & Agreement
subtitle: Form, Structure and Sense
learning_objectives: The Core: Master subject-verb agreement and consistent tense
The Skill: Match verbs to subjects even when separated by distractors
The Problem: SAT hides subjects behind prepositional phrases and interrupting clauses
Key Strategy: The 3-Phase MATCH Strategy for 100% provable verb forms

content.heading: The Main Quest
bullet_points: Decode the true subject hiding behind distractors
Master singular vs. plural verb agreement
Apply the 3-Phase MATCH Strategy for certainty
Handle tricky collective nouns and special cases

content.heading: PHASE 1: Find the True Subject
content.subtitle: The SAT's Favorite Trick—Hiding Subjects Behind Distractors

core_principle.title: The Golden Rule
core_principle.description: Verbs must agree with their SUBJECT in number (singular/plural). The SAT hides subjects behind prepositional phrases, interrupting clauses, and complex constructions.

strategy_steps.title: Find the VERB First
strategy_steps.description: Locate the action or state of being word
examples: The box of papers (is/are) heavy → Verb: is/are
The team of researchers (study/studies) climate → Verb: study/studies
strategy_steps.why: Starting with the verb helps you ask 'Who or what does this?'

strategy_steps.title: Ask 'Who or What' Does the Action
examples: What is heavy? → The box (NOT papers)
Who studies? → The team (NOT researchers)

strategy_steps.title: CROSS OUT Distractors
strategy_steps.description: Eliminate prepositional phrases and interrupting elements

distractor_types.definition: Phrases starting with: of, in, on, at, by, with, from, to, for, about, between, among
examples: The box [of papers] is heavy
The collection [of rare books] belongs to the library
Students [in the class] are studying
distractor_types.rule: NEVER use the object of a preposition as your subject

distractor_types.definition: Set off by commas, dashes, or parentheses
examples: The scientist, along with her assistants, works late
The book—which has 500 pages—is difficult
The CEO (who founded the company) plans to retire
distractor_types.rule: These add information but don't change the subject

examples: The teacher, along with the students, is attending
The CEO, as well as the managers, plans the strategy
distractor_types.rule: These DON'T make the subject plural—only 'and' does that

strategy_steps.title: Identify Subject Number
strategy_steps.description: Is the TRUE subject singular or plural?

worked_example.sentence: The collection of rare books from various countries belong to the university.
process: Step 3: Cross out → The collection [of rare books] [from various countries] belong

examples: The team wins the championship. (team = one unit)
The committee has decided. (committee = one unit)
The family agrees on the plan. (family = one unit)
The jury reaches a verdict. (jury = one unit)
special_cases.common_collectives: team, committee, family, group, jury, class, audience, government, company, staff
special_cases.key_insight: If the group acts as ONE entity → singular verb

special_cases.rule: Verb agrees with the CLOSEST subject

examples.sentence: Either the cats or the dog needs food.
Neither the professor nor the students understand the problem.
Either the manager or the employees are responsible.

special_cases.strategy: Always identify which subject is CLOSER to the verb

special_cases.rule: Real subject comes AFTER the verb
special_cases.why_tricky: 'There' and 'here' are not subjects—they're placeholder words

examples.sentence: There is a problem with the system.

special_cases.strategy: Flip the sentence: 'A problem is there' → easier to see agreement

examples: Each of the students has a laptop.
Everyone in the room is listening.
Neither of the options seems ideal.
always_singular.trap: Don't be fooled by 'of the [plural noun]'—the pronoun is still singular

examples: Both of the theories are valid.
Many of the participants have arrived.

depends_on_context.rule: Depends on the noun they refer to
examples: Some of the water is contaminated. (water = singular)
Some of the students are absent. (students = plural)
The teacher and the student are meeting.
Coffee and tea are popular beverages.
Physics and chemistry require strong math skills.

exception.when: Compound subject refers to ONE thing or person
examples: Peanut butter and jelly is my favorite sandwich. (one type of sandwich)
My friend and colleague is arriving tomorrow. (same person)

elements.reveal: When you see 'of the [plural noun]' after a subject, IGNORE the plural noun. The true subject comes before 'of': Each of the students HAS (not have).

core_principle.title: The Consistency Principle
core_principle.description: Verb tenses should remain consistent unless there's a clear logical reason to shift. Unnecessary tense shifts confuse readers about when actions occur.

tense_rules.when: All actions happen at the same time

examples.consistent: Maria studied hard and passed her exam with flying colors.
examples.why: Both actions in past, both use past tense

examples.inconsistent: Maria studied hard and passes her exam with flying colors.
examples.why_wrong: Illogical shift from past to present

tense_rules.when: Actions occur at different times—MUST shift

examples.correct: The scientist discovered the pattern in 2020, and researchers continue to study it today.
examples.why: Past action (discovered) then ongoing action (continue) = logical shift

examples.correct: The book was published in 1960, but it remains relevant today.
examples.why: Past event (was published) followed by current state (remains) = logical shift

guidelines.example: The experiment began in 2019. Researchers collected data for two years. The results showed significant patterns.
Water boils at 100°C. Gravity pulls objects toward Earth. The sun rises in the east.
In the novel, the protagonist struggles with identity. She eventually discovers her true purpose.

signal_words.title: Time-Shift Signal Words
signal_words.description: These words indicate when a tense shift is logical
signals: now, today, currently, at present → shift to present
then, at that time, previously, earlier → stay in/shift to past
since then, until now → shift from past to present
when, while, before, after → show time relationship between actions

error_detection.title: How to Spot Tense Errors
steps: Step 1: Identify the time frame of the passage (past, present, or mixed)
Step 2: Check each verb against the established time frame
Step 3: Look for signal words indicating intentional time shifts
Step 4: Verify that any tense shifts are logically justified

slides.title: Guided Practice: The Strategy in Action

content.heading: Let's Apply All 3 Phases Together
content.passage: The team of researchers, along with their graduate assistant, were studying climate patterns when they discovered an unexpected trend. Each of their findings have contributed to a growing understanding of global weather systems. There was several factors that influenced their conclusions, and neither the original data nor the recent measurements was sufficient alone. The implications of their work extends far beyond their initial expectations.
content.question: Which choice best corrects all verb errors in the passage?

walkthrough.question: Sentence 1: What's the true subject of 'were studying'?
walkthrough.reasoning: Cross out: The team [of researchers], [along with their graduate assistant] → Subject: team (collective noun = singular)

walkthrough.question: Sentence 1: Is 'were' correct for singular subject 'team'?
walkthrough.reasoning: Collective nouns take singular verbs when acting as one unit

walkthrough.question: Sentence 2: What's the subject of 'have contributed'?
walkthrough.reasoning: Cross out: Each [of their findings] → Subject: each (always singular)

walkthrough.question: Sentence 2: Is 'have' correct for 'each'?
walkthrough.reasoning: 'Each' is always singular, even when followed by plural noun

walkthrough.phase: PHASE 2: Apply Special Rules - There is/are
walkthrough.question: Sentence 3: What comes after 'There was'?
walkthrough.reasoning: Real subject comes after verb in 'there is/are' constructions

walkthrough.question: Sentence 3: What about 'neither...nor'?
walkthrough.reasoning: Neither...nor rule: verb matches closest subject

walkthrough.question: Sentence 4: What's the subject of 'extends'?
walkthrough.reasoning: Cross out: The implications [of their work] → Subject: implications (plural)

walkthrough.question: Now evaluate answer choices with all corrections

options_analysis.text: ...was studying... Each...has contributed... There were several factors... neither...nor...were sufficient... implications...extend...
options_analysis.analysis:
✓ CORRECT—All errors fixed:
- 'was studying' (team = singular) ✓
- 'has contributed' (each = singular) ✓
- 'were' (several factors = plural) ✓
- 'were sufficient' (measurements closest, plural) ✓
- 'extend' (implications = plural) ✓

options_analysis.text: ...were studying... Each...has contributed... There were... neither...were... implications...extend...
options_analysis.analysis: ✗ Keeps 'were studying' error—team should be 'was' (singular collective noun)

options_analysis.text: ...was studying... Each...have contributed... There was... neither...was... implications...extend...
options_analysis.analysis: ✗ Multiple errors: 'have contributed' should be 'has' (each = singular), 'was' should be 'were' (factors = plural), 'was sufficient' should be 'were' (measurements = plural)

options_analysis.text: ...were studying... Each...has contributed... There were... neither...were... implications...extends...
options_analysis.analysis: ✗ Two errors: 'were studying' should be 'was' (team = singular), 'extends' should be 'extend' (implications = plural)

slides.title: Your Turn: Apply the MATCH Strategy

content.heading: Independent Practice
content.instructions: Use all 3 phases: Find True Subject → Apply Special Rules → Check Tense Consistency
content.passage: The collection of ancient artifacts, discovered in multiple locations, provide valuable insights into early civilizations. Each of the items have been carefully preserved and studied. There is many questions about the artifacts' origins, but neither the archaeological evidence nor the historical records offers definitive answers. The team continue their research and hopes to resolve these mysteries.
content.question: Which choice best corrects all verb errors in the passage?
content.strategy_reminder: Phase 1: Cross out distractors to find true subject. Phase 2: Check for collective nouns, indefinite pronouns, there is/are, neither/nor. Phase 3: Verify tense consistency.

options: The collection of ancient artifacts, discovered in multiple locations, provides valuable insights into early civilizations. Each of the items has been carefully preserved and studied. There are many questions about the artifacts' origins, but neither the archaeological evidence nor the historical records offer definitive answers. The team continues its research and hopes to resolve these mysteries.

The collection of ancient artifacts, discovered in multiple locations, provide valuable insights into early civilizations. Each of the items have been carefully preserved and studied. There are many questions about the artifacts' origins, but neither the archaeological evidence nor the historical records offers definitive answers. The team continue their research and hopes to resolve these mysteries.

The collection of ancient artifacts, discovered in multiple locations, provides valuable insights into early civilizations. Each of the items have been carefully preserved and studied. There is many questions about the artifacts' origins, but neither the archaeological evidence nor the historical records offers definitive answers. The team continues its research and hopes to resolve these mysteries.

The collection of ancient artifacts, discovered in multiple locations, provide valuable insights into early civilizations. Each of the items has been carefully preserved and studied. There are many questions about the artifacts' origins, but neither the archaeological evidence nor the historical records offer definitive answers. The team continues its research and hopes to resolve these mysteries.
content.explanation:
Let's apply the 3 phases:

PHASE 1: Find true subjects by crossing out distractors:
- 'The collection [of ancient artifacts], [discovered in multiple locations]' → collection (singular)
- 'Each [of the items]' → each (singular)
- 'There is/are [many questions]' → questions (plural, real subject)
- 'neither...nor...' → closest subject determines verb
- 'The team' → team (singular collective)

PHASE 2: Apply special rules:
- 'collection' = singular → 'provides' ✓
- 'each' = always singular → 'has' ✓
- 'questions' = plural → 'are' ✓
- 'neither...nor records offer' → 'records' (plural) is closest → 'offer' ✓
- 'team' = collective noun, singular → 'continues' ✓

A: ✓ CORRECT—All errors fixed
B: Keeps 'provide' and 'have' errors
C: Wrong 'is' (should be 'are'), wrong 'have' (should be 'has')
D: Keeps 'provide' error, wrong 'offer' (should match singular 'records'—actually this is tricky, but 'records' is plural so 'offer' is correct)

content.heading: Master These Patterns—Perfect Agreement Every Time

rows: The team wins / The committee decides
Neither cats nor dog needs / Neither dog nor cats need
There are problems / Here comes the bus
Each of the students has / Every option seems
The teacher and student are meeting
The teacher, along with students, is attending

content.expert_insight: The SAT's #1 verb trick: hiding singular subjects behind plural phrases. Always cross out 'of the [plural noun]' to find the true subject.

content.heading: Verb Agreement & Tense Mastery
key_points: Phase 1: Find true subject by crossing out prepositional phrases and interrupting clauses
Phase 2: Master special cases—collective nouns (singular), either/or (closest subject), there is/are (subject after verb), indefinite pronouns (each = singular)
Phase 3: Keep tense consistent unless there's a logical reason to shift time frames
The 100% Rule: 'Of the [plural noun]' is always a distractor—ignore it and find the real subject
content.strategy_reminder: Remember MATCH: Mark distractors, Assess subject number, Test special cases, Check tense consistency, Handle agreement rules
content.expert_insight: Collective nouns (team, committee) are singular. 'Each' is always singular even with 'of the [plural]'. Either/or agrees with the closest subject.

practice_transition.text: Ready to apply your mastery? Let's practice with authentic SAT verb questions!

content.message: Outstanding! You've mastered verb agreement and tense with surgical precision.

slides.title: Mastery Check
slides.question:
The team of researchers, along with their graduate assistant, were studying climate patterns when they discovered an unexpected trend. Each of their findings have contributed to a growing understanding of global weather systems. There was several factors that influenced their conclusions, and neither the original data nor the recent measurements was sufficient alone. The implications of their work extends far beyond their initial expectations.

Which choice best corrects all verb errors in the passage?
options: ...was studying... Each...has contributed... There were several factors... neither...nor...were sufficient... implications...extend...
...were studying... Each...has contributed... There were... neither...were... implications...extend...
...was studying... Each...have contributed... There was... neither...was... implications...extend...
...were studying... Each...has contributed... There were... neither...were... implications...extends...
slides.explanation:
Error analysis with 3 phases:

PHASE 1 - Find subjects by crossing out:
- 'team [of researchers], [along with assistant]' → team (singular)
- 'Each [of their findings]' → each (singular)
- 'There...several factors' → factors (plural, real subject)
- 'neither data nor measurements' → measurements closest (plural)
- 'implications [of their work]' → implications (plural)

PHASE 2 - Apply special rules:
- Collective noun 'team' → singular verb 'was'
- Indefinite pronoun 'each' → singular verb 'has'
- 'There' construction → verb matches 'factors' (plural) → 'were'
- Neither/nor → matches closest 'measurements' (plural) → 'were'
- Regular plural 'implications' → 'extend'

A: ✓ CORRECT—All 5 errors fixed

B: Keeps 'were studying' error (team = singular)

C: Multiple errors—'have' should be 'has', 'was' should be 'were', 'was sufficient' should be 'were'

D: Two errors—'were studying' and 'extends' (should be 'extend')

strategy_card.title: The MATCH Strategy Quick Reference

steps: Cross out prepositional phrases (of, in, with, etc.)
Cross out interrupting clauses (along with, as well as)
Identify if subject is singular or plural
There is/are → real subject comes after
Each, every, either, neither → always singular

strategy_card.the_100_rule: Always cross out 'of the [plural noun]' to find the true subject. Collective nouns are singular. 'Each' is always singular.

common_mistakes: Using plural verb because of 'of the [plural noun]' after singular subject
Treating collective nouns (team, committee) as plural
Forgetting 'each' is always singular, even with 'of the [plural]'
Not checking which subject is closest in either/or, neither/nor

agreement_quick_reference.There Is/Are: Real subject comes after → There are problems
agreement_quick_reference.Each/Every: Always singular → Each has, Every student needs
agreement_quick_reference.Along With: Doesn't make subject plural → Teacher, along with students, is

strategy_integration.key_innovation: 3-Phase MATCH Strategy: Find True Subject → Apply Special Rules → Check Tense
